titleStmt.title: A chast mayd in Cheape-Side¨ A pleasant conceited comedy neuer before printed. As it hath beene often acted at the Swan on the Banke-side, by the Lady Elizabeth her Seruants. By Thomas Midelton Gent.
titleStmt.author: Middleton, Thomas, d. 1627.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Francis Constable dwelling at the signe of the Crane in Pauls Church-yard,

note.p: Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

div.p: A CHAST MAYD IN CHEAPE-SIDE. A Pleasant conceited Comedy neuer before printed. As it hath beene often acted at the Swan on the Banke-side, by the Lady ELIZABETH her Seruants.
LONDON, Printed for Francis Constable dwelling at the signe of the Crane in Pauls Church-yard. 1630.

div.head: The Names of the principall Persons.

list.item: Sr WALTER WHOREHOVND, A Suter to MOLL.
Sr OLIVER KIXE, and his Wife, Kin to Sr WALT.
Mr ALLWIT, and his Wife, Whom Sr WALT. keepes.
TVCHWOOD SENIOR, and his Wife, A decayed Gentleman.
TVCHWOOD IVNIOR, Another Suter to MOLL.

div.head: Actus Primus.
div.stage: Enter Maudline and Moll, a Shop being discouered.

sp.speaker: Maudline.
sp.p: HAue you playd ouer all your old Lessons o'the Virginals?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Yes, you are a dull Mayd alate, me thinkes you had need haue somewhat to quicken your Greene Sicknesse, doe you weepe? A Husband. Had not such a peece of Flesh been ordayned, what had vs Wiues been good for? To make Sallets, or else cryd vp and downe for Sampier. To see the difference of these Seasons, when I was of your youth, I was lightsome, and quicke, two yeeres before I was married. You fit for a Knights bed, drowsie browd, dull eyed, drossie sprited, I hold my life you haue forgot your Dauncing: When was the Dauncer with you?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: The last weeke.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Last weeke, when I was of your bord, he mist me not a night, I was kept at it, I tooke delight to learne, and he to teach me, prittie browne Gentleman, he tooke pleasure in my company, but you are dull, nothing comes nimbly from you, you daunce like a Plummers Daughter, and deserue two thousand pound in Lead to your marriage, and not in Gold-Smithes Ware.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Now what's the din betwixt Mother and Daughter, ha?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Faith small, telling your Daughter Mary of her Errors.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Errors, nay the Citie cannot hold you Wife, but you must needs fetch words from Westminster, I ha done I faith, has no Atturneys Clarke beene here a late, and changed his Halfe-Crowne-peece his Mother sent him, or rather cozend you with a guilded Two-pence, to bring the word in fashion, for her faults or crackes, in dutie and obedience, terme em eeue so sweet Wife. As there is no Woman made without a Flaw, your purest Lawnes haue Frayes, and Cambrickes Brackes.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: But 'tis a Husband sowders vp all Crackes.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: What is he come Sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Sr Walters come.

He was met at Holbourne Bridge, and in his company, a proper faire young Gentlewoman, which I guesse by her red Hayre, and other ranke descriptions, to be his landed Neece, brought out of Wales, which Tim our Sonne (the Cambridge Boy) must marry.
'Tis a match of Sr Walters owne making to bind vs to him, and our Heires for euer.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: We are honord then, if this Baggage would be humble, and kisse him with deuotion when he enters.

I cannot get her for my life
to instruct her Hand thus, before and after, which a Knight will looke for, before and after.
I haue told her still, 'tis the wauing of a Woman dose often moue a Man, and preuailes strongly.
But sweet, ha you sent to Cambridge, (has Tim word an't?)

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Had word iust the day after when you sent him the Siluer Spoone to eat his Broath in the Hall, amongst the Gentlemen Commoners.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O 'twas timely.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: A Letter from a Gentleman in Cambridge.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: O one of Hobsons Porters, thou art well-come.
I told thee Maud we should heare from Tim. Amantissimis charissimisque ambobus parentibus patri & matri.

sp.speaker: Maudl
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Nay by my troth, I know not, aske not me, he's growne too verball, this Learning is a great Witch.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.l: Pray let me see it, I was wont to vnderstand him.
Amantissimus charissimus, he has sent the Carryers Man he sayes: ambobus parentibus, for a paire of Boots: patri & matri, pay the Porter, or it makes no matter.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Yes by my faith Mistris, there's no true construction in that, I haue tooke a great deale of paines, and come from the Bell sweating. Let me come to'te, for I was a Schollar forty yeers ago, 'tis thus I warrant you: Matri, it makes no matter: ambobus parentibus, for a paire of Boots: patri, pay the Porter: amantissimis charissimis, he's the Carryers Man, and his name is Sims, and there he sayes true, forsooth my name is Sims indeed, I haue not forgot all my learning. A Money matter, I thought I should hit on't.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Goe thou art an old Fox, ther's a Tester for thee.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: If I see your Worship at Goose Faire, I haue a Dish of Birds for you.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Why dost dwell at Bow?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: All my life time Sir I could euer say Bo, to a Goose. Farewell to your Worship.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: A merry Porter.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How can he choose but be so, comming with Cambridge Letters from our Sonne Tim?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What's here, maximus diligo, Faith I must to my learned Counsell with this geere, 'twill nere be discernd else.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Goe to my Cousen then, at Innes of Court.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Fye they are all for French, they speake no Latine.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: The Parson then will doe it.

div.stage: Enter a Gentleman with a Chayne.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Nay he disclaimes it, calles Latine Papistry, he will not deale with it. What ist you lacke Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Pray weigh this Chayne.

div.stage: Enter Sir Walter Whorehound, Welch Gentlewoman, and Dauy Dahanna.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Now Wench thou art well-come to the Heart of the Citie of London.

sp.speaker: W. Gent.
sp.p: Dugat a whee.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: You can thanke me in English if you list.

sp.speaker: W. Gent.
sp.p: I can Sir simply.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: 'Twill serue to passe Wench, 'twas strange that I should lye with thee so often, to leaue thee without English, that were vnnaturall, I bring thee vp to turne thee into Gold Wench, and make thy fortune shine like your bright Trade, a Gold-Smithes Shop sets out a Citie Mayd. Dauy Dahanna, not a word.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Mum, mum Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Here you must passe for a pure Virgine.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Pure Welch Virgine, she lost her Maydenhead in Brekenocke-Shire.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I heare you mumble Dauy.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I haue Teeth Sir, I need not mumble yet this forty yeeres.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: The Knaue bites plaguely.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What's your price Sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: A hundred pound Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: A hundred markes the vtmost, 'tis not for me else.
What Sr Walter Whorehound?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O Death.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.l: Why Daughter.
Faith the Baggage a bashful Girle Sir, these young things are shamefast, besides you haue a presence sweet Sr Walter, able to daunt a Mayd brought vp i'the Citie,
A braue Court Spirit makes our Virgines quiuer, and kisse with trembling Thighes. Yet see she comes Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Why how now prettie Mistris, now I haue caught you. What can you iniure so your time to strey thus from your faithfull Seruant.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Pish, stop your words good Knight, 'twill make her blush else, which wound to high for the Daughters of the Freedome, honor, and faithfull Seruant, they are complements for the Worthy's of Whitehall, or Greenwitch, eene plaine, sufficient, subsidy words serues vs Sir. And is this Gentlewoman your worthy Neece?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: You may be bold with her on these termes, 'tis she Sir, Heire to some nineteene Mountaines.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Blesse vs all, you ouer-whelme me Sir with loue and riches.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: And all as high as Pauls.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Here's worke I faith.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How sayest thou Dauy?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Higher Sir by farre, you cannot see the top of 'em.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What Man? Maudline salute this Gentlewoman, our Daughter if things hit right.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: My Knight with a brace of Footmen, is come and brought vp his Ewe Mutton, to find a Ram at London, I must hasten it, or else picke a Famine, her Bloods mine, and that's the surest. Well Knight, that choyse spoy is onely kept for me.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Turne not to me till thou mayst lawfully, it but whets my stomacke, which is too sharpe set already. Read that note carefully, keepe me from suspition still, nor know my zeale but in thy Heart: read and send but thy liking in three words, I'le be at hand to take it.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: O turne Sir, turne.
A poore plaine Boy, an Vniuersitie Man, proceeds next Lent to a Batcheler of Art, he will be call'd Sr Yellowhammer then ouer all Cambridge, and that's halfe a Knight.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Please you draw neere, and tast the well-come of the Citie Sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Come good Sr Walter, and your vertuous Neece here.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: 'Tis manners to take kindnesse.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Lead 'em in Wife.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Your company Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: I'le giue't you instantly.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: How strangely busie is the Diuell and riches,
Poore Soule kept in too hard, her Mothers Eye, is cruell toward her, being to him, 'twere a good mirth now to set him a worke to make her wedding Ring. I must about it.
Rather then the gaine should fall to a Stranger, 'twas honestie in me to enrich my Father.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l:
The Girle is wondrous peuish, I feare nothing, but that she's taken with some other loue,
then all's quite dasht, that must be narrowly lookt to, we cannot be too wary in our Children. What ist you lack?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: O nothing now, all that I wish is present.
I would haue a wedding Ring made for a Gentlewoman, with all speed that may be.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Of what weight Sir?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Of some halfe ounce, stand faire and comely, with the Sparke of a Diamond.
Sir 'twere pittie to lose the least grace.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Pray let's see it, indeed Sir 'tis a pure one.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: So is the Mistris.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Haue you the widenesse of her Finger Sir?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Yes sure I thinke I haue her measure about me, good faith 'tis downe, I cannot show't you,
I must pull too many things out to be certaine.
Let me see, long, and slender, and neatly ioynted,
Iust such another Gentlewoman that's your Daughter Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: And therefore Sir no Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: I protest I neuer saw two Maids handed more alike
I'le nere seeke farther, if you'le giue me leaue Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: If you dare venture by her Finger Sir.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: I, and I'le bide all losse Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Say you so Sir, let's see hether Girle.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Shall I make bold with your finger Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Your pleasure Sir.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: That fits her to a haire Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What's your Posie now Sir?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Masse that's true, Posie I faith eene thus Sir.
Loue that's wise, blinds Parents Eyes.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: How, how, If I may speake without offence Sir,
I hold my life

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Goe too, you'le pardon me?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Pardon you? I Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Will you I faith?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Yes faith I will.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: You'le steale away some Mans Daughter, am I nere you?

Doe you turne aside? You Gentlemen are mad Wage, I
wonder things can be so warily carried, and Parents blinded so, but the're serued right that haue two Eyes, and were so dull a fight.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Thy doome take hold of thee.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: To morrow noone shall shew your Ring well done.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Being so 'tis soone, thankes, and your leaue sweet Gentlewoman

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Sir you are well-come.
O were I made of wishes, I went with thee.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Come now we'le see how the rules goe within.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: That robs my Ioy, there I loose all I win.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Honestie wash my Eyes, I haue spy'd a Witall.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: What Dauy Dahanna, well-come from North Wales
I faith, and is Sr Walter come?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Now come to Towne Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Into the Mayds sweet Dauy, and giue order his Chamber be made ready instantly, my Wife's as great as she can wallow Dauy, and longs for nothing but pickled Coucombers, and his comming, and now she shall ha'te Boy.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: She's sure of them Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Thy verie sight will hold my Wife in pleasure, till the Knight come himselfe. Goin, in, in Dauy.
The Founders come to Towne, I am like a Man finding a Table furnish't to his hand, as mine is still to me, prayes for the Founder, blesse the right Worshipfull, the good Founders life.

I thanke him, h'as maintain'd my House this ten yeeres, not onely keepes my Wife, but a keepes me, and all my Family, I am at his Table, he gets me all my Children, and payes the Nurse, monthly, or weekely, puts me to nothing, rent, nor Church duties, not so much as the Scauenger, the happiest state that euer Man was borne to.
I walke out in a morning, come to breake-fast,
Find excellent Cheere, a good Fier in Winter,
Looke in my Coale-house about Midsommer-eeue,
That's full, fiue or sixe Chaldorne, new layd vp,
Looke in my backe yeard, I shall find a steeple
Made vp with Kentish Fagot's, which o're-lookes
The Water-House and the Wind-milles, I say nothing
But smile, and pin the doore, when she lyes in,
As now she's euen vpon the point of grunting,
A Lady lyes not in like her, there's her imbossings,
Embrodring, spanglings, and I know not what,
As if she lay with all the gaudy Shops
In Gressams Bursse about her, then her restoratiues,
Able to set vp a young Pothecarie,
And richly stocke, the Foreman of a Drug-shop.
Her Sugar by whole Loaues, her Wines by Rundlets.
I see these things, but like a happy Man,
I pay for none at all, yet Fooles think's mine,
I haue the name, and in his Gold I shine.
And where some Merchants would in Soule kisse Hell,
To buy a Paradice for their Wines, and dye
Their Conscience in the Bloods of prodigall Heires,
To decke their Night-peece, yet all this being done,
Eaten with iealousie to the inmost Bone,
As what affliction Nature more constraynes,
Then feed the Wife plumpe, for anothers veynes.
These torments stand I freed of, I am as cleere
From iealousie of a Wife, as from the charge.
O two miraculous blessings, 'tis the Knight
Hath tooke that labour, all out of my hands,
I may sit still and play, he's iealouse for me,
Watches her steps, sets spyes, I liue at ease,
He has both the cost and torment, when the strings
Of his Heart freats, I feed, laugh, or sing,
La dildo, dildo la dildo, la dildo dildo de dildo.

sp.p: What has he got a singing in his Head now?
Now's out of worke he falles to making Dildo's.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Now Sirs, Sr Walters come.
Is our Master come?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Your Master, what am I?
Doe not you know Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Pray am not I your Master?
O you are but our Mistresses Husband.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ergo Knaue, your Master.
Negatur argumentum. Here comes Sr Walter, now a stands bare as well as we, make the most of him he's but one peepe aboue a Seruingman, and so much his Hornes make him.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How dost Iacke?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Proud of your Worships health Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How does your Wife?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Eene after your owne making Sir,
She's a tumbler a faith, the Nose and Belly meets.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: The'ile part in time againe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: At the good houre, they will and please your worship.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Here Sirra, pull off my Boots. Put on, but on Iacke.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I thanke your kind worship Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Slippers, Heart you are sleepy.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The game begins already.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Pish, put on Iacke.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Now I must doe it, or he'le be as angry now, as if I had put it on at first bidding, 'tis but obseruing, 'tis but obseruing a Mans humour once, and he may ha' him by the Nose all his life.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: What entertainment has layne open here,
No strangers in my absence?

sp.speaker: 1 Seru.
sp.p: Sure Sir not any.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: His iealousie begins, am not I happy now
That can laugh inward whil'st his Marrow melts?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How doe you satisfie me?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Good Sir be patient.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: For two months absence I'le be satisfied.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: No liuing Creature entred.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Entred, come sweare.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: You will not heare me out Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Yes I'le heare't out Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Seru.
sp.p: Sir he can tell himselfe.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Heart he can tell,
Doe you thinke I'le trust him? As a Vsurer
With forfeited Lordships. Him, ô monsterous iniury!
Beleeue him, can the Diuell speake ill of Darkenesse?
What can you say Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Of my soule and conscience Sir, she's a Wife as honest of her Body to me, as any Lords proud Lady can be.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Yet by your leaue, I heard you were once offring to goe to bed to her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No I protest Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Heart if you doe, you shall take all, I'le marry.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O I beseech you Sir,

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: That wakes the Slaue, and keepes his Flesh in awe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I'le stop that gap
Where e're I find it open, I haue poysoned
His hopes in marriage already,
Some old rich Widdowes, and some landed Virgines,
And I'le fall to worke still before I'le lose him,
He's yet too sweet to part from.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: God-den Father.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha Villaine, peace.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: God-den Father.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Peace Bastard, should he heare em. These are two foolish Children, they doe not know the Gentleman that sits there.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Oh Wat, how dost Nicke? Goe to Schoole,
Ply your Bookes Boyes, ha?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Where's your Legges Whore sons? They should kneele indeed if they could say their Prayers.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Let me see, stay,
How shall I dispose of these two Brats now
When I am married, for they must not mingle
Amongst my Children that I get in Wedlocke,
'Twill make foule worke that, and rayse many stormes.
I'le bind Wat Prentice to a Goldsmith, my Father Yellowh.
As fit as can be. Nick with some Vintner, good, Goldsmith
And Vintner, there will be Wine in Boles I faith.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.l: Sweet Knight
Welcome, I haue all my longings now in Towne,
Now well-come the good houre.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How cheeres my Mistris?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Made lightsome, eene by him that made me heauy.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Me thinkes she shewes gallantly, like a Moone at full Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: True, and if she beare a Male child, there's the Man in the Moone Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: 'Tis but the Boy in the Moone yet Goodman Calfe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: There was a Man, the Boy had neuer beene there else.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: It shall be yours Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No by my troth, I'le sweare it's none of mine, let him that got it keepe it, thus doe I rid my selfe of feare, Lye soft, sleepe hard, drinke Wine, and eat good cheere.

div.head: Actus Secundus.
div.stage: Enter Tuchwood Senior, and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Twill be so tedious Sir to liue from you,
But that necessitie must be obeyed.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: I would it might not Wife, the tediousnesse
Will be the most part mine, that vnderstand
The blessings I haue in thee, so to part
That driues the torment to a knowing Heart,
But as thou say'st, we must giue way to need
All liue awhile asunder, our desires
Are both too fruitfull for our barren fortunes.
How aduers runs the desteny of some Creatures,
Some onely can get riches and no Children,
We onely can get Children and no riches,
Then 'tis the prudents part to checke our willes,
And till our state rise, make our Bloods lye still.
'Life euerie yeere a Child, and some yeeres two,
Besides, drinkings abroad, that's neuer reckon'd,
This geere will not hold out.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir for a time, I'le take the curtesie of my Vnkles House
If you be pleas'd to like on't, till prosperitie
Looke with a friendly Eye vpon our states.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Honest Wife I thanke thee, I ne're knew
The perfect treasure thou brought'st with thee more
Then at this instant minute. A Man's happy
When he's at poorest that has match't his Soule
As rightly as his Body. Had I married
A sensuall Foole now, as 'tis hard to scape it
'Mongst Gentlewomen of our time, she would ha' hang'd
About my Necke, and neuer left her hold
Till she had kist me into wanton businesses,
Which at the waking of my better Iudgement
I should haue curst most bitterly,
And layd a thicker vengance on my act
Then miserie of the Birth, which were enough
If it were borne to greatnesse, whereas mine
Is sure of beggerie, though it were got in Wine.
Fulnesse of Ioy sheweth the goodnesse in thee,
Thou art a matchlesse Wife, Farwell my Ioy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I shall not want your sight?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: I'le see thee often,
Talke in mirth, and play at kisses with thee,
Any thing Wench but what may beget Beggers,
There I giue o're the Set, throw downe the Cards,
And dare not take them vp.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Your will be mine Sir.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: This does not onely make her honestie perfect,
But her discretion, and approues her Iudgement.
Had her desire beene wanton, they'd beene blamelesse
In being lawfull euer, but of all Creatures
I hold that Wife a most vnmatched treasure,
That can vnto her fortunes fixe her pleasure,
And not vnto her Blood, this is like wedlocke,
The feast of marriage is not Lust but Loue,
And care of the estate, when I please Blood,
Meerely I sing, and sucke out others, then
'Tis many a wisemans fault, but of all Men
I am the most vnfortunate in that game
That euer pleas'd both Genders, I ne're play'd yet
Vnder a Bastard, the poore Wenches cursse me
To the Pit where e're I come, they were ne're serued so,
But vs'd to haue more words then one to a bargaine,
I haue such a fatall Finger in such businesse
I must forth with't, chiefely for Countrey Wenches,
For euerie Haruest I shall hinder Hay-making,
sp.stage: Enter a Wench with a Child.
sp.l: I had no lesse then seuen lay in last Progresse,
Within three weekes of one anothers time.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: O Snaphance, haue I found you.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: How Snaphance?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Doe you see your workemanship,
Nay turne not from it, nor offer to escape, for if you doe,
I'le cry it through the Streets, and follow you.
Your name may well be called Tuchwood, a Pox on you,
You doe but touch and take, thou hast vndone me,
I was a Mayd before, I can bring a Certificate for it,
From both the Church-Wardens.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: I'le haue the Parsons Hand too, or I'le not yeeld to't.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Thou shalt haue more thou Villaine, nothing grieues me, but Ellen my poore cousen in Darbishiere, thou hast crack't her marriage quite, she'le haue a bout with thee.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Faith when she will I'le haue a bout with her.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: A Law bout Sir I meane.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: True, Lawyers vse such bouts as other Men doe,
And if that be all thy griefe, I'le tender her a Husband,
I keepe of purpose two or three Gulls in pickle
To eat such Mutten with, and she shall chuse one.
Doe but in courtesie faith Wench excuse me,
Of this halfe yeard of Flesh, in which I thinke it wants
A Nayle or two.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: No, thou shalt find Villaine
It hath right shape, and all the Nayles it should haue.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Faith I am poore, doe a charitable deed Wench,
I am a younger Brother, and haue nothing.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Nothing, thou hast too much thou lying villaine
Vnlesse thou wert more thankefull.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: I haue no dwelling,
I brake vp House but this morning, Pray thee pittie me,
I am a good Fellow, faith haue beene too kind
To people of your Gender, if I ha'te
Without my Belly, none of your Sexe shall want it,
That word has beene of force to moue a Woman.
There's trickes enough to rid thy Hand on't Wench,
Some rich-mans Porch, to morrow before day,
Or else anone i'the euening, twentie deuises,
Here's all I haue, I faith, take purse and all,
And would I were rid of all the Ware i'the Shop so.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Where I find manly dealings I am pitifull,
This shall not trouble you.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: And I protest Wench, the next I'le keepe my selfe.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Soft, let it be got first.
This is the fifth, if e're I venture more
Where I now goe for a Mayd, may I ride for a Whore.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: what shift shele make now with this peece of flesh
In this strict time of Lent, I cannot imagine,
Flesh dare not peepe abroad now, I haue knowne
This Citie now aboue this seuen yeers,
But I protest in better state of gouernement,
I neuer knew it yet, nor euer heard of,
There has beene more religious wholesome Lawes
In the halfe cirkle of a yeere erected
For common good, then memorie euer knew of,
sp.stage: Enter Sir Oliuer Kix, and his Lady.
sp.l: Setting apart corruption of Promoters,
And other poysonous Officers that infect
And with a venemous breath taint euerie goodnesse.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O that e're I was begot, or bred, or borne.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Be content sweet Wife.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: What's here to doe now?
I hold my life she's in deepe passion
For the imprisonment of Veale and Mutton
Now kept in Garets, weepes for some Calues Head now,
Me thinkes her Husbands Head might serue with Bacon.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hist.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Patience sweet Wife.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Brother I haue sought you strangely.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Why what's the businesse?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: With all speed thou canst procure a Licence for me.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: How, a Licence?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Cuds-foot she's lost else, I shall misse her euer.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Nay sure thou shalt not misse so faire a marke
For thirteene shillings foure pence.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Thankes by hundreds.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Nay pray thee cease, I'le be at more cost yet,
Thou know'st we are rich enough.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: All but in blessings,
And there the Begger goes beyond vs. O, ô, ô,
To be seuen yeeres a Wife and not a Child, ô not a Child.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Sweet Wife haue patience.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Can any Woman haue a greater cut?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I know 'tis great, but what of that Wife?
I cannot doe with all, there's things making
By thine owne Doctors aduice at Poticaries,
I spare for nothing Wife, no if the price
Were fortie markes a spoone-full,
I'de giue a thousand pound to purchase fruitfulnesse,
'Tis but bating so many good workes
In the erecting of Bridewels and Spittle-houses,
And so fetch it vp againe, for hauing none
I meane to make good deeds my Children.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Giue me but those good deeds, and I'le find Children.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Hang thee, thou hast had too many.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Thou ly'st breuitie.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: O horrible, dar'st thou call me breuitie?
Dar'st thou be so short with me?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Thou deseruest worse.
Thinke but vpon the goodly Lands and Liuings
That's kept backe through want on't.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Talke not on't pray thee,
Thou'lt make me play the Woman, and weepe too.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis our dry barrennesse puffes vp Sr Walter,
None gets by your not-getting, but that Knight,
He's made by th' meanes, and fats his fortunes, shortly
In a great Dowry with a Gold-Smiths Daughter.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: They may be all deceiued,
Be but you patient Wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I haue suffred a long time.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Suffer thy Heart out, a Poxe suffer thee.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay thee, thou desertlesse Slaue.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Come, come, I ha' done,
You'le to the Gossiping of Mr Allwits Child?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes, to my much ioy,
Euerie one gets before me, there's my Sister
Was married but at Bartholmew-eeue last,
And she can haue two Children at a birth,
O one of them, one of them would ha' seru'd my turne.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Sorrow consume thee, thou art still crossing me,
And know'st my nature.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: O Mistris, weeping or rayling,
That's our House harmony.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What say'st Iugg?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.p: The sweetest newes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What ist Wench?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: Throw downe your Doctors Drugges,
They're all but Heretikes, I bring certaine remedy
That has beene taught, and proued, and neuer fayl'd.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: O that, that, that or nothing.

sp.speaker: Mayd
sp.l: There's a Gentleman,
I haply haue his Name too, that has got
Nine Children by one Water that he vseth,
It neuer misses, they come so fast vpon him,
He was faine to giue it ouer.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: His name sweet Iugg?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: One Mr Tuchwood, a fine Gentleman,
But run behind-hand much with getting Children.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Ist possible?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: Why Sir, he'le vndertake,
Vsing that Water, within fifteene yeere,
For all your wealth, to make you a poore Man,
You shall so swarme with Children.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I'le venture that I faith.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That shall you Husband.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.p: But I must tell you first, he's very deere.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: No matter, what serues wealth for?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: True sweet Husband,
There's Land to come, Put case his Water stands me
In some fiue hundred pound a pint,
'Twill fetch a thousand, and a Kersten Soule.
I'le about it.
And that's worth all sweet Husband.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I'le goe bid Gossips presently my selfe,
That's all the worke I'le doe, nor need I stirre,
But that it is my pleasure to walke forth
And ayre my selfe a little, I am ty'd to nothing
In this businesse, what I doe is meerely recreation,
Not constraint.
Here's running to and fro, Nurse vpon Nurse,
Three Chare women, besides maids & neighbors children.
Fye, what a trouble haue I rid my Hands on,
It makes me sweat to thinke on't.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How now Iacke?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I am going to bid Gossips for your Wps child Sir,
A goodly Girle I faith, giue you ioy on her,
She looks as if she had two thousand pound to her portion
And run away with a Taylor, A fine plumpe black ei'd slut,
Vnder correction Sir,
I take delight to see her: Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Doe you call Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I call not you, I call the Wet Nurse hither,
Giue me the wet Nurse, I 'tis thou,
Come hither, come hither,
Lets see her once againe; I cannot chuse
But busse her thrice an hower.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: You may be proud on't Sir,
'Tis the best peece of worke that e're you did.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Think'st thou so Nurse, What sayest to Wat and Nicke?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: They're pretie children both, but here's a wench
Will be a knocker.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Pup say'st thou me so, pup little Countesse,
Faith Sir I thanke your Worship for this Girle,
Ten thousand times, and vpward.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I am glad I haue her for you Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Here take her in Nurse, wipe her, and giue her Spoone-meat.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Wipe your Mouth Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: And now about these Gossips.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Get but two, I'le stand for one my selfe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: To your owne Child Sir?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: The better pollicie, it preuents suspition,
'Tis good to play with rumor at all weapons.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Troth I commend your care Sir, 'tis a thing
That I should ne're haue thought on.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: The more Slaue,
When Man turnes base, out goes his Soules pure flame,
The fat of ease o're-throwes the eyes of shame.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I am studying who to get for Godmother
Sutable to your Worship, Now I ha' thought on't.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: I'le ease you of that care, and please my selfe in't
My Loue the Goldsmithes Daughter, if I send,
Her Father will command her, Dauy Dahumma.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I'le fit your Worship then with a Male Partner.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A kind proper Gentleman, Brother to Mr Tuchwood.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I know Tuchwood, has he a Brother liuing?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A neat Batchelor.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Now we know him, we'le make shift with him
Dispatch the time drawes neere, Come hither Dauy.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: In troth I pittie him, he ne're stands still,
Poore Knight what paines he takes, sends this way one,
That way another, has not an houres leasure,
I would not haue thy toyle, for all thy pleasure,
Ha, how now, what are these that stand so close
At the Street-corner, pricking vp their Eares,
And snuffing vp their Noses, like rich-mens Dogges
When the first Course goes in? By the masse Promoters,
'Tis so I hold my life, and planted there
To arrest the dead Corps of poore Calues and Sheepe,
Like rauenous Creditors, that will not suffer
The Bodyes of their poore departed Debtors
To goe to'th graue, but eene in Death to vex
And stay the Corps, with Billes of Middlesex,
This Lent will fat the whoresons vp with Sweetbreds,
And lard their whores with Lambe-stones, what their gols
Can clutch, goes presently to their Mols and Dols,
The Bawds will be so fat with what they earne,
Their Chins will hang like Vdders, by Easter-eeue,
And being stroak't, will giue the Milke of Witches,
How did the Mungrels heare my wife lyes in?
Well, I may baffle 'em gallantly, By your fauour Gentlemen
I am a stranger both vnto the Citie,
And to her carnall stricktnesse.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Good, Your will Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Pray tell me where one dwells that kils this Lent.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: How kils? Come hither Dicke,
A Bird, a Bird.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: What ist that you would haue?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Faith any Flesh,
But I long especially for Veale and Greene-sauce.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Greene-Goose, you shall be sau'st.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I haue halfe a scornefull stomacke, no Fish will be admitted.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Not this Lent Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Lent, what cares Colon here for Lent?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: You say well Sir,
Good reason that the Colon of a Gentleman
As you were lately pleas'd to terme your worship Sir,
Should be fulfill'd with answerable food,
To sharpen Blood, delight Health, and tickle Nature,
Were you directed hither to this Street Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: That I was, I marry.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: And the Butcher belike
Should kill, and sell close in some vpper Roome?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Some Apple-loft as I take it, or a Cole-house,
I know not which I faith.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: Either will serue,
This Butcher shall kisse Newgate, lesse he turne vp the
Bottome of the Pocket of his Apron,
You goe to seeke him?

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Where you shall not find him,
I'le buy, walke by your Noses with my Flesh,
Sheepe-biting Mungrels, Hand-basket Free-booters,
My Wife lyes in, a footra for Promoters.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: That shall not serue your turn, what a Rogue's this, how cunningly he came ouer vs?

div.stage: Enter a Man with Meat in a Basket.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Husht, stand close.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: I haue scap't well thus farre, they say the Knaues are wondrous hot and busie.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: By your leaue Sir,
We must see what you haue vnder your Cloake there.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Haue? I haue nothing.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: No, doe you tell vs that, what makes this lumpe sticke out then, we must see Sir.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: What will you see Sir, a paire of Sheets, and two of my Wiues foule Smocks, going to the Washers?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: O we loue that sight well, you cannot please vs better: What doe you gull vs, call you these Shirts and Smockes?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.l: Now a Poxe choake you,
You haue cozend me and fiue of my Wiues kinred
Of a good Dinner, we must make it vp now
With Herrings and Milke-potage.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: 'Tis all Veale.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: All Veale, Poxe the worse lucke, I promis'd faithfully to send this morning a fat quarter of Lambe, to a kind Gentlewoman in Turnebull street that longs, and how I'me crost.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Let's share this, and see what hap comes next then.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: Agreed, stand close againe, another bootie,
What's he?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Sir, by your fauour.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Meaning me Sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Good Mr Oliuer, cry thee mercie, I faith.
What hast thou there?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: A Racke of Mutton Sir, and halfe a Lambe,
You know my Mistrisses dyet.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Goe, goe, we see thee not, away, keepe close,
Heart let him passe, thou'lt neuer haue the wit
To know our benefactors.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: I haue forgot him.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: 'Tis M. Beggerlands man the wealthy Merchant
That is in fee with vs.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Now I haue a feeling of him.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: You know he purchast the whole Lent together
Gaue vs ten groats a peece on Ash-wensday.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: True, true.

div.stage: Enter a Wench with a Basket, and a Child in it vnder a Loyne of Mutton.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: A Wench.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Why then stand close indeed.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Women had need of wit, if they'le shift here,
And she that hath wit, may shift any-where.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Looke, looke, poore Foole,
She has left the Rumpe vncouer'd too,
More to betray her, this is like a Murdrer,
That will out-face the deed with a bloody Band.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: What time of the yeere ist Sister?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: O sweet Gentlemen, I am a poore Seruant,
Let me goe.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: You shall Wench, but this must stay with vs.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: O you vndoe me Sir,
'Tis for a welthy Gentlewoman that takes Physicke Sir,
The Doctor do's allow my Mistris Mutton,
O as you tender the deere life of a Gentlewoman,
I'le bring my Master to you, he shall shew you
A true authoritie from the higher powers,
And I'le run euerie foot.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: Well, leaue your Basket then,
And run and spare not.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Will you sweare then to me,
To keepe it till I come.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Now by this light I will.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: What say you Gentleman?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: What a strange Wench 'tis?
Would we might perish else.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Nay then I run Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: And ne're returne I hope.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: A politike Baggage,
She makes vs sweare to keepe it,
I prethe looke what market she hath made.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Imprimis Sir, a good fat Loyne of Mutton,
What comes next vnder this Cloath?
Now for a quarter of Lambe.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Not for a Shoulder of Mutton.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Done.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Why done Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: By the masse I feele I haue lost,
'Tis of more weight I faith.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Some Loyne of Veale?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: No faith, here's a Lambes Head,
I feele that plainly, why yet win my wager.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Swounds what's here?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: A Child.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: A Poxe of all dissembling cunning Whores.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Here's an vnlucky Breakefast.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: What shal's doe?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: The Queane made vs sweare to keepe it too.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: We might leaue it else.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: Villanous strange,
'Life had she none to gull, but poore Promoters,
That watch hard for a liuing.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Halfe our gettings must run in Suger-sope,
And Nurses wages now, besides many a pound of Sope,
And Tallow, we haue need to get Loynes of Mutton still,
To saue Suet to change for Candles.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Nothing mads me, but this was a Lambs head with you, you felt it, she has made Calues heads of vs.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Prethe no more on't,
There's time to get it vp, it is not come
To Mid-Lent Sunday yet.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: I am so angry, I'le watch no more to day.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Faith nor I neither.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Why then I'le make a motion.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Well, what ist?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Let's e'ne goe to the Checker at Queene-hiue and rost the Loyne of Mutton, till young Flood, then send the Child to Branford.

div.stage: Enter Allwit in one of Sir Walters Sutes, and Dauy trussing him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: 'Tis a busie day at our House Dauy.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Alwayes the Kursning day Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Trusse, trusse me Dauy.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: No matter and you were hang'd Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How do's this Sute fit me Dauy?

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Excellent neatly, my Masters things were euer fit for you Sir, e'ne to a Haire you know.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Thou hast hit it right Dauy,
We euer iumpt in one, this ten yeeres Dauy,
sp.stage: Enter a Seruant with a Box.
sp.l: So well said, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Your Comfit-makers Man Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O sweet youth, into the Nurse quicke,
Quicke, 'tis time I faith,
Your Mistris will be here?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: She was setting forth Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Here comes our Gossips now, O I shall haue such kissing worke to day, Sweet Mistris Underman welcome I faith.

sp.speaker: 1 Pur.
sp.l: Giue you ioy of your fine Girle Sir,
Grant that her education may be pure,
And become one of the faithfull.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Thankes to your Sisterly wishes Mr Underman.

sp.speaker: 2 Pur.
sp.p: Are any of the Brethrens Wiues yet come?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: There are some Wiues within, and some at home.

sp.speaker: 1 Pur.
sp.p: Verily thankes Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Verily you are an Asse forsooth,
I must sit all these times, or there's no Musicke,
Here comes a friendly and familier payer,
Now I like these Wenches well.

sp.speaker: 1 Goss.
sp.p: How do'st sirra?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Faith well I thanke you Neighbor, and how do'st thou?

sp.speaker: 2 Goss.
sp.p: Want nothing, but such getting Sir as thine.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: My gettings wench, they are poore.

sp.speaker: 1 Goss.
sp.l: Fye that thou'lt say so,
Th'ast as fine Children as a Man can get.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.l: I as a Man can get,
And that's my Master.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: They are pretie foolish things,
Put to making in minutes,
I ne're stand long about 'em,
Will you walke in Wenches?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: The hapiest meeting that our soules could wish for
Here's the Ring ready, I am beholding vnto your Fathers hast, h'as kept his howre.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: He neuer kept it better.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Backe, be silent.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Mistris and Partner, I will put you both into one Cup.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.l: Into one Cup, most proper,
A fitting complement for a Gold-smiths Daughter.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Yes Sir, that's he must be your Worships Partner
In this dayes businesse, Mr Tuchwoods Brother.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I embrace your acquaintance Sir.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: It vowes your seruice Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: It's neere high time, come Mr All-wit.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ready Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Wil't please you walke?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Sir I obey your time.

div.stage: Enter Midwife with the Child, and the Gossips to the Kursning.

sp.speaker: 1 Goss.
sp.p: Good Mris Yellowhammer.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: In faith I will not.

sp.speaker: 1 Goss.
sp.p: Indeed it shall be yours

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: I haue sworne I saith.

sp.speaker: 1 Goss.
sp.p: I'le stand still then.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: So will you let the Child goe without company
And make me forsworne.

sp.speaker: 1 Goss.
sp.p: You are such another Creature.

sp.speaker: 2 Goss.
sp.p: Before me, I pray come downe a little.

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.p: Not a whit, I hope I know my place.

sp.speaker: 2 Goss.
sp.p: Your place, great wonder sure, are you any better then a Comfit-makers wife.

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.p: And that's as good at all times as a Pothicaries.

sp.speaker: 2 Goss.
sp.p: Ye lye, yet I forbeare you too.

sp.speaker: 1 Pur.
sp.p: Come sweet Sister, we goe in vnitie, and shew the fruits of peace like Children of the Spirit.

sp.speaker: 2 Pur.
sp.p: I loue lowlinesse.

sp.speaker: 4 Goss.
sp.l: True, so say I, though they striue more,
There comes as proud behind, as goes before.

sp.speaker: 5 Goss.
sp.p: Euerie inch I faith.

div.head: Actus Tertius.
div.stage: Enter Tuchwood Iunior, and a Parson.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: O Sir, if euer you felt the force of loue, pittie it in me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Yes, though I ne're was married Sir,
I haue felt the force of loue from good mens daughters,
And some that will be Mayds yet three yeeres hence.
Haue you got a Licence?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Here 'tis ready Sir.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: That's well.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: The Ring and all things perfect, she'le steale hither.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: She shall be welcome Sir, I'le not be long
A clapping you together.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: O here she's come Sir.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What's he?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: My honest Brother.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Quicke, make hast Sirs.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: You must dispatch with all the speed you can,
For I shall be mist straight, I made hard shift
For this small time I haue.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then I'le not linger,
Place that Ring vpon her Finger,
This the Finger playes the part,
Whose master Veine shoots from the Heart,
Now ioyne Hands.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Which I will seuer,
And so ne're againe meet neuer.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O we are betray'd.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Hard fate.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I am strucke with wonder.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Was this the politike fetch, thou misticall baggage
Thou disobedient strumpet,
And were so wise to send for her to such an end,

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Now I disclaime the end, you'le make me mad.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: And what are you Sir?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: And you cannot see with those two Glasses, put on a paire more.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: I dreampt of anger still, here take your Ring Sir,
Ha this, life 'tis the same, abhominable,
Did not I sell this Ring?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: I thinke you did, you receiued money for't.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Heart, harke you Knight,
Here's no inconscionable villany,
Set me a worke to make the Wedding Ring,
And come with an intent to steale my Daughter,
Did euer run-a-way match it?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: 'This your Brother Sir?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: He can tell that as well as I.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: The verie Poesie mockes me to my face,
Loue that's wise, blinds Parents eyes,
I thanke your wisedome Sir for blinding of vs,
We haue good hope to recouer our sight shortly,
In the meane time I will locke vp this baggage,
As carefully as my Gold, she shall see as little Sunne
If a close Roome or so can keepe her from the light on't.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O sweet Father, for Loues sake pittie me.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Farewell Sir, all content blesse thee,
And take this for comfort,
Though violence keepe me, thou canst loose me neuer,
I am euer thine although we part for euer.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: I we shall part you Minkes.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Your acquaintance Sir, came verie lately,
Yet it came too soone,
I must here-after know you for no friend,
But one that I must shun like Pestilence,
Or the Disease of Lust.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Like enough Sir, you ha' tane me at the worst time for words that e're ye pick't out, faith doe not wrong me Sir.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Looke after him and spare not, there he walkes
That neuer yet receiued baffling, you'r blest
More then e're I knew, goe take your rest.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I pardon you, you are both loosers.

div.stage: A Bed thrust out vpon the Stage, Allwits Wife in it, Enter all the Gossips.

sp.speaker: 1 Goss.
sp.l: How ist Woman, we haue brought you home
A Kursen Soule.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I, I thanke your paines.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: And verily well kursend, i'the right way,
Without Idolatry or Superstition,
After the pure manner of Amsterdam.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sit downe good Neighbours, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: At hand forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Looke they haue all low stooles

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: They haue forsooth.

sp.speaker: 2 Goss.
sp.l: Bring the Child hither Nurse, how say you now
Gossip, ist not a chopping Girle, so like the Father?

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.l: As if it had beene spit out of his Mouth,
By'd, nos'd, and brow'd as like a Girle can be,
Onely indeed it has the Mothers Mouth.

sp.speaker: 2 Goss.
sp.p: The Mothers Mouth vp and downe, vp and downe.

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.p: 'Tis a large Child, she's but a little Woman.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: No beleeue me, a verie spynie Creature, but all hart,
Well metteld, like the faithfull to endure
Her tribulation here, and rayse vp seed.

sp.speaker: 2 Goss.
sp.p: She had a sore labour on't I warrant you, you can tell Neighbour.

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.l: O she had great speed,
We were afrayd once,
But she made vs all haue ioyfull hearts againe,
'Tis a good Soule I faith,
The Midwife found her a most cheerefull Daughter.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: 'Tis the spirit, the Sisters are all like her,

div.stage: Enter Sir Walter with two Spoones and Plate and Allwit.

sp.speaker: 2 Goss.
sp.p: O here comes the chiefe Gossip Neighbours.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: The fatnesse of your wishes to you all Ladyes.

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.l: O deer sweet gentleman, what fine words he has
The fatnesse of our wishes.

sp.speaker: 2 Goss.
sp.p: Calles vs all Ladyes.

sp.speaker: 4 Goss.
sp.p: I promise you a fine Gentleman, and a courteous.

sp.speaker: 2 Goss.
sp.p: Me thinkes her Husband shewes like a Clowne to him.

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.p: I would not care what Clowne my Husband were too, so I had such fine Children.

sp.speaker: 2 Goss.
sp.p: She's all fine Children Gossip.

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.p: I, and see how fast they come.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Children are blessings, if they be got with zeale,
By the Brethren, as I haue fiue at home.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: The worst is past, I hope now Gossip.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: So I hope to good Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Why then so hope I too for company,
I haue nothing to doe else.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: A poore remembrance Lady,
To the loue of the Babe, I pray accept of it.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: O you are at too much charge Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Goss.
sp.p: Looke, looke, what has he giuen her, what Ist Gossip?

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.p: Now by my faith a faire high standing Cup, and two great Postle Spoones, one of them gilt.

sp.speaker: 1 Pur.
sp.p: Sure that was Iudas then with the red Beard.

sp.speaker: 2 Pur.
sp.p: I would not feed my daughter with that spoone for all the World, for feare of colouring her Heyre, Red Hayre the Brethren like not, it consumes them much, 'tis not the Sisters colour.

div.stage: Enter Nurse with Comfits and Wine.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Well said Nurse,
About, about with them amongst the Gossips,
Now out comes all the tasseld Handkerchers,
They are spred abroad betweene their Knees already,
Now in goes the long Fingers that are wash't
Some thrice a day in Vrin, my Wife vses it,
Now we shall haue such pocketing,
See how they lurch at the lower end.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Come hither Nurse.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Againe, she has taken twice already.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: I had forgot a Sisters Child that's sicke.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p:
A Pox it seemes your purity loues sweet things well that puts in thrice together, had this beene all my cost now I had beene beggerd, these Women haue no consciences at sweet meats, where e're they come, see and they haue not culd out all the long Plumbes too, they haue left nothing here but short riggle-tayle-Comfits, not worth mouthing, no mar'le I heard a Citizen complaine once, that his Wiues Belly onely broke his Backe: Mine had beene all in fitters seuen yeeres since, but for this worthy Knight, that with a
prop vpholds my Wife and me, and all my estate buried in Bucklers-berrie.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Here Mris Yellowhammer, and Neighbours,
To you all that haue taken paines with me,
All the good Wiues at once.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: I'le answer for them,
They wish all health and strength,
And that you may couragiously goe forward,
To performe the like and many such,
Like a true Sister with Motherly bearing.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Now the cups trole about to wet the gossips whistles
It poures downe I faith, they neuer thinke of payment.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Fill againe Nurse.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Now blesse thee, two at once, I'le stay no longer,
It would kill me and if I pay'd for't,
Will it please you to walke downe and leaue the women.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: With all my Heart Iacke.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Troth I cannot blame you.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Sit you all merry Ladyes.

sp.speaker: All Goss.
sp.p: Thanke your Worship Sir.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Thanke your Worship Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Pox twice tipple ye, you are last & lowest.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Bring hither that same Cup-Nurse, I would faine driue away this hup Antichristian griefe.

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.l: See Gossip and she lyes not in like a Countesse,
Would I had such a Husband for my Daughter.

sp.speaker: 4 Goss.
sp.p: Is not she toward marriage?

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.p: O no sweet Gossip.

sp.speaker: 4 Goss.
sp.p: Why she's nineteene?

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.l: I that she was last Lammas,
But she has a fault Gossip, a secret fault.

sp.speaker: 4 Goss.
sp.p: A fault, what ist?

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.p: I'le tell you when I haue drunke.

sp.speaker: 4 Goss.
sp.p: Wine can doe that I see, that friendship cannot.

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.p: And now I'le tell you Gossip, she's too free.

sp.speaker: 4 Goss.
sp.p: To free?

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.p: O I, she cannot lye dry in her Bed.

sp.speaker: 4 Goss.
sp.p: What, and nineteene?

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.p: 'Tis as I tell you Gossip.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Speake with me Nurse, who ist?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: A Gentleman from Cambridge,
I thinke it be your Soone forsooth.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: 'Tis my Soone Tim I faith,
Prethe call him vp among the Women,
'Twill imbolden him well,
For he wants nothing but audacitie,
'Would Would the Welch gentlewoman at home were here now.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Is your Sonne come forsooth?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Yes from the Vniuersitie forsooth.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis great ioy on yee.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: There's a great marriage towards for him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A marriage?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Yes sure, a hughe Heire in Wales,
At least to nineteene Mountaines,
Besides her Goods and Cattell.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O, I'me betray'd.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.l: What gone againe, run after him good Nurse,
He's so bashfull, that's the spoyle of youth,
In the Vniuersitie they're kept still to Men,
And ne're trayn'd vp to Womens company.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis a great spoyle of youth indeed.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Your Mother will haue it so.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Why Sonne, why Tim,
What must I rise and fetch you? For shame Sonne.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Mother you doe intreat like a fresh Woman,
'Tis against the Lawes of the Vniuersitie,
For any that has answered vnder Batchelor
To thrust 'mongst married Wiues.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Come we'le excuse you here.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Call vp my Tutor Mother, and I care not.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: What is your Tutor come, haue you brought him vp?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I ha' not brought him vp, he stands at dore,
Negatur, there's Logicke to begin with you Mother.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.l: Run call the gentleman nurse, he's my sons tutor
Here eat some Plumbes.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Come I from Cambridge, and offer me six plumbs?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Why how now Tim,
Will not your old trickes yet be left?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Seru'd like a Child,
When I haue answer'd vnder Batcheler?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: You'le neuer lin till I make your Tutor whip you, you know how I seru'd you once at the Free Schoole in Pauls Church-yeard?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O monstrous absurditie,
Ne're was the like in Cambridge since my time,
'Life whip a Batcheler, yow'ld be laught at soundly,
Let not my Tutor heare you,
'Twould be a Iest through the whole Vniuersitie,
No more words Mother.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Is this your Tutor Tim?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Yes surely Lady, I am the man that brought him in League with Logicke, and red the Dunces to him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: That did he Mother, but now I haue 'em all in my owne Pate, and can as well read 'em to others.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: That can he Mistris, for they flow naturally from him.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: I'me the more beholding to your paynes Sir.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Non ideo sane ideo sane.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: True, he was an Ideot indeed,
When he went out of London, but now he's well mended.
Did you receiue the two Goose-pies I sent you?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: And eat them hartely, thankes to your Worship.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: 'Tis my Sonne Tim, I pray bid him welcome Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Tim, harke you Timothius Mother, Timothius.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How, shall I deny your Name? Timothius quoth he? Faith there's a name, 'tis my Sonne Tim forsooth.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You're welcome Mr Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O this is horrible, she wets as she kisses,
Your Handkercher sweet Tutor, to wipe them off, as fast as they come on.

sp.speaker: 2 Goss.
sp.p: Welcome from Cambridge.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: This is intollerable, This woman has a villanous sweet breath, did she not stinke of Comfits, Helpe me sweet Tutor, or I shall rub my Lips off.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I'le goe kisse the lower end the whil'st.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Perhaps that's the sweeter, and we shall dispatch the sooner.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Let me come next, Welcome from the Welspring of discipline, that waters all the Brethren.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Hoyst I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: 3 Goss.
sp.p: O blesse the Woman, Mr Vnderman.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: 'Tis but the common affliction of the faithfull,
We must embrace our falles.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I'me glad I scap't it, it was some rotten kisse sure,
It dropt downe before it came at me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Here's a noyse, not parted yet?
Hyda, a Looking-glasse, they haue drunke so hard in Plate,
That some of them had need of other Vessels,
Yonder's the brauest Shew.

sp.speaker: All Goss.
sp.p: Where? Where Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Come along presently by the Pissing-conduit,
With two braue Drums and a Standert-bearer.

sp.speaker: All Goss.
sp.p: O Braue.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Come Tutor.

sp.speaker: All Goss.
sp.p: Farwell sweet Gossip.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I thanke you all for your paynes.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Feed and grow strong.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: You had more need to sleepe then eat,
Goe take a nap with some of the Brethren, goe,
And rise vp a well edified, boldified Sister,
O here's a day of toyle well past o're,
Able to make a Citizen Hare mad,
How hot they haue made the Roome with their thicke Bums,
Do'st not feele it Dauy?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Monstrous strong Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What's here vnder the Stooles?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Nothing but wet Sir, some Wine spilt here belike.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ist no worse think'st thou?
Faire Needle worke Stooles, cost nothing with them Dauy

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Nor you neither I faith.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Looke how they haue layd them,
Ee'ne as they lye themselues, with their Heeles vp,
How they haue shufflled vp the Rushes too Dauy
With their short figging little shittle-corke-heels,
These Women can let nothing stand as they find it,
But what's the secret thou'st about to tell me
My honest Dauy?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: If you should disclose it Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Life rip my Belly vp to the Throat then Dauy.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: My Master's vpon Marriage.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Marriage Dauy, send me to hanging rather.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I haue stong him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: When, where, what is she Dauy?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: E'ne the same was Gossip, and gaue the Spoone.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I haue no time to stay, nor scarce can speake,
I'le stop those wheeles, or all the worke will breake.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I knew 'twold pricke, Thus doe I fashion still
All mine owne ends by him and his ranke toyle,
'Tis my desire to keepe him still from marriage,
Being his poore neerest Kinsman, I may fare
The better at his death, there my hopes build
Since my Lady Kixe is dry, and hath no Child.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Y'are in the happiest way to enrich your selfe,
And pleasure me Brother, as Mans feet can tread in,
For though she be lock't vp, her vow is fix't onely to me;
Then time shall neuer grieue me, for by that vow,
E'ne absent inioy her, assuredly confirm'd that none
Else shall, which will make tedious yeeres seeme gamefull
To me, In the meane space lose you no time sweet brother,
You haue the meanes to strike at this Knights fortunes,
And lay him leuell with his bankrout merit,
Get but his Wife with Child, perch at tree top,
And shake the golden fruit into her Lap,
About it before she weepe her selfe to a dry ground,
And whine out all her goodnesse.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Prethe cease, I find a too much aptness in my blood
For such a businesse without prouocation,
You might 'well spar'd this banket of Oringoes,
Hartechokes, Potatoes, and your butter'd Crabbe,
They were fitter kept for your owne wedding dinner.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Nay and you'le follow my suit, & saue my purse too
Fortune doats on me, he's in happy case
Finds such an honest friend i'the Common place.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Life what makes thee so merry? thou hast no cause
That I could heare of lately since thy crosses,
Vnlesse there be newes come, with new additions.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Why there thou hast it right,
I looke for her this Euening Brother.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: How's that, looke for her?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: I will deliuer you of the wonder streight Brother,
By the firme secresie, and kind assistance
Of a good Wench i'the House, who made of pittie,
Weighing the case her owne, she's lead through Gutters,
Strange hidden wayes, which none but Loue could find,
Or ha' the Heart to venture, I expect her
Where you would little thinke.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: I care not where, so she be safe, and yours.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Hope telles me so,
But from your loue and time my peace must grow.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: You know the worst then brother, now to my Kix
The barren he and she, they're i'the next Roome,
But to say which of their two humors hold them
Now at this instant, I cannot say truly.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Thou lyest Barrennesse.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: O ist that time of day, giue you ioy of your tongue
There's nothing else good in you, this their life
The whole day from eyes open to eyes shut,
Kissing or scolding, and then must be made friends,
Then rayle the second part of the first fit out,
And then be pleas'd againe, no Man knowes which way,
Fall out like Giants, and fall in like Children,
Their Fruit can witnesse as much.

div.stage: Enter Sir Oliuer Kix, and his Lady.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: 'Tis thy fault.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Mine, Drouth and coldnesse?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Thine, 'tis thou art barren.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I barren, ó life that I durst but speake now,
In mine owne Iustice, in mine owne Right, I barren,
'Twas otherwayes with me when I was at Court,
I was ne're call'd so till I was married.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I'le be deuorc't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Be hang'd, I need not wish it,
That will come too soone to thee:
I may say, Marriage and hanging goes by destiny,
For all the goodnesse I can find in't yet.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I'le giue vp House, & keepe some fruitfull whore,
Like an old Batcheler in a Tradsmans Chamber,
She and her Children shall haue all.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where be they?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Pray cease,
When there are friendlier courses tooke for you,
To get and multiply within your House,
At your owne proper costs in spight of censure,
Me thinkes an honest peace might be establish't.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: What with her? Neuer.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Sweet Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: You worke all in vaine.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Then he doth all like thee.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Let me intreat Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Singlenesse confound her,
I tooke her with one Smocke.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But indeed you came not so single,
When you came from Shipboard.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Heart she bit sore there,
Prethe make's friends.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Ist come to that, the peale begins to cease.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I'le sell all at an Out-cry.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Doe thy worst Slaue,
Good sweet Sir bring vs into loue againe.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Some would thinke this impossible to compasse,
Pray let this storme fly ouer.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Good Sir pardon me, I'me Master of this House,
Which I'le sell presently, I'le clap vp Billes this Euening.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Lady friends come?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: If e're ye lou'd Woman, talke not on't Sir, what friends with him? good faith do you think I'me mad with one that's scarce the hinder quarter of a Man?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Thou art nothing of a Woman.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Would I were lesse then nothing.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Nay prethe what do'st meane?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I cannot please you.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I faith thou art a good Soule, he lyes that sayes it,
Busse, busse, pretie Rogue.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You care not for me.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Can any man tell now which way they came in?
By this light I'le be hang'd then.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Is the Drinke come?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Here's a little Viall of Almond-milke
That stood me in some three pence.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I hope to see thee wench within these few yeeres,
Cirkled with Children, pranking vp a Girle,
And putting Iewels in their little Eares,
Fine sport I saith.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I had you beene ought Husband,
It had beene done ere this time.

sp.speaker: S. Ol
sp.l: Had I bin ought, hang thee, had'st thou bin ought,
But a crosse thing I euer found thee.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Thou art a Grub to say so.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: A Pox on thee.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: By this light they are out againe at the same dore,
And no Man can tell which way,
Come here's your Drinke Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I will not take it now Sir,
And I were sure to get three Boyes ere Midnight.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Why there thou shew'st now of what breed thou com'st
To hinder generation, O thou Villaine,
That knowes how crookedly the World goes with vs,
For want of Heires, yet put by all good fortune.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Hang strumpet, I will take it now in spight.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Then you must ride vpon't fiue houres.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I meane so, Within there?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Saddle the white Mare,
I'le take a Whore along, and ride to Ware.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Ride to the Diuel.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I'le plague you euerie way,
Looke ye, doe you see, 'tis gone.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A Pox goe with it.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I curse and spare not now.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Stirre vp and downe sir, you must not stand.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Nay I'me not giuen to standing.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: So much the better sir for the—

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I neuer could stand long in one place yet,
I learnt it of my Father, euer figient,
How if I crost this Sir?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: O passing good Sir, and would shew well a Horsebacke: When you come to your Inne, If you leapt ouer a ioynt-stoole or two, 'twere not amisse although you brake your necke Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: What say you to a Table thus high Sir?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Nothing better Sir, if it be furnished with good Victuals. You remember how the bargaine runs about this businesse?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Or else I had a bad Head: you must receiue Sir foure hundred pounds of me at foure seuerall payments:
One hundred pound now in hand.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Right, that I haue Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Another hundred when my Wifes is quicke: the third when she's brought a bed: and the last hundred when the Child cryes, For if it should be still borne, it doth no good Sir.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: All this is euen still, a little faster Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Not a whit Sir,
I'me in an excellent pace for any Physicke,

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Your white Mares ready.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I shall vp presently: One kisse, and farewell.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Thou shalt haue two Loue.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Expect me about three.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: With all my Heart Sweet.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: By this light they haue forgot their anger since,
And are as farre in againe as e're they were,
Which way the Diuell came they, Haart I saw 'em not,
Their wayes are beyond finding out. Come sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: How must I take mine Sir?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Cleane contrarie, yours must be taken lying.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A Bed Sir?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: A Bed, or where you will for your owne ease,
Your Coach will serue.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: The Physicke must needs please.

div.head: Actus Quartus.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Negatur argumentum Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Probo tibi Pupill, stultus non est animal rationale.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Faller is sane.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Quaso ut taceas, probo tibi.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Quomodo probae domine.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Stultus non habet rationem, ergo non est animal rationale.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sic argumentaris domine, stultus non habet rationem, ergo non est animal rationale, negatur argumentum againe Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Argumentum itterum probo tibi domine, qui non participat de ratione nullo modo potest vocari rationalibus, but stultus non participat de ratione, ergo stultus nullo modo potest dicere rationalis.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Participat.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Sic disputus, qui participat quomodo participat.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ut homo, probabo tibi in silagismo.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Hunc proba.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sic probo domine, stultus est homo sicut tu & ego sum, homo est animal rationele, sicut stultus est animal rationale.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Here's nothing but disputing all the day long with 'em.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Sic disputus, stultus est homo sicut tu & ego sum homo est animal rationale, sicut stultus est animal rationale.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Your reasons are both good what e're they be
Pray giue them or'e, faith you'le tire your selues,
What's the matter betweene you?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nothing but reasoning about a Foole Mother.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: About a Foole Son, alas what need you trouble your heads about that, none of vs all but knowes what a Foole is.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Why what's a Foole Mother?
I come to you now.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Why one that's married before he has wit.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: 'Tis prettie I faith, and well guest of a Woman neuer brought vp at the Vniuersitie: but bring forth what Foole you will Mother, I'le proue him to be as reasonable a Creature, as my selfe or my Tutor here.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Fye 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Nay he shall do't forsooth.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: 'Tis the easiest thing to proue a Foole by Logicke,
By Logicke I'le proue any thing.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: What thou wilt not?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'le proue a Whore to be an honest Woman.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Nay by my faith, she must proue that her selfe, or Logicke will neuer do't.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: 'Twill do't I tell you.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Some in this Street would giue a thousand pounds that you could proue their Wiues so.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Faith I can, and all their Daughters too, though they had three Bastards. When comes your Taylor hither?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Why what of him?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: By Logicke I'le proue him to be a Man,
Let him come when he will.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: How hard at first was Learning to him? Truly
Sir I thought he would neuer a tooke the Latine Tongue.
How many Accidences doe you thinke he wore out e're he came to his Grammer?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Some three or foure.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Beleeue me Sir some foure and thirtie.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Pish I made haberdins of 'em in Church porches

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: He was eight yeeres in his Grammer, and stucke horribly at a foolish place there call'd Asse in presenti.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Pox I haue it here now.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: He so sham'd me once before an honest Gentleman that knew me when I was a Mayd

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: These women must haue all out.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Quidest Gramatica? Sayes the Gentleman to him (I shall remember by a sweet sweet token) but nothing could he answer.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: How now Pupill, ha, Quid est Gramatica?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Grammatica? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Nay doe not laugh Sonne, but let me heare you say it now: There was one word went so prettily off the Gentlemans tongue, I shall remember it the longest day of my life.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Come, Quid est Gramatica?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Are you not asham'd Tutor, Gramatica? Why Recte scribendi atque loquendi ars, ser-reuerence of my Mother.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: That was it I faith: Why now Sonne I see you are a deepe Scholler: And Mr Tutor a word I pray, let vs with-draw a little into my Husbands Chamber, I'le send in the North-Wales Gentlewoman to him, she lookes for wooing: I'le put together both, and locke the Dore.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I giue great approbation to your conclusion.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I mar'le what this Gentlewoman should be,
That I should haue in marriage, she's a stranger to me:
I wonder what my Parents meane I faith,
To match me with a stranger so:
A Mayd that's neither kisse nor kin to me:
Life doe they thinke I haue no more care of my Body,
Then to lye with one that I ne're knew,
A meere stranger,
One that ne're went to Schoole with me neither,
Nor euer play-fellowes together,
They'r mightily o're-seene in't me thinkes,
They say she has Mountaines to her marriage,
She's full of Cattell, some two thousand Runts,
Now what the meaning of these Runts should be,
My Tutor cannot tell me,
I haue look't in Riders Dixcionarie for the Letter R,
And there I can heare no tydings of these Runts neither,
Vnlesse they should be Rumford Hogges,
I know them not,
And here she comes,
If I know what to say to her now
In the way of marriage, I'me no Graduate,
Me thinkes I faith 'tis bouldly done of her
To come into my Chamber being but a stranger,
She shall not say I'me so proud yet, but I'le speake to her,
Marry as I will order it,
She shall take no hold of my words I'le warrant her,
She lookes and makes a coursey,
Salue tu quoque puella puleherima,
Quid vis nescio nec sane curo,
Tully's owne phrase to a Hart.

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.l: I know not what he meanes,
A Sutor quoth a?
I hold my life he vnderstands no English.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Ferter me hercule tu virgo,
Wallia vt opibus abundis maximis.

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.l: What's this fertur and abundundis?
He mockes me sure, and calles me a bundle of Farts.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I haue no Latine word now for their Runts, I'le make some shift or other: Itterum dico opibus abundat maximis montibus & fontibus & vt ita dicam Rontibus, attamen vero homauculus ego sum natura simule arte bachalarius lecto profecto non parata.

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.l: This is most strange, may be he can speake Welch,
Auedera whee comrage, der due cog foginis.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Cog foggin, I scorne to cog with her, I'le tell her so too in a word neere her owne Language: Ego non cogo.

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.p: Rhegosin a whiggin harle ron corid ambre.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: By my faith she's a good scholler, I see that already
She has the Tongues plaine, I hold my life she has traueld,
What will folkes say? There goes the learned couple,
Faith if the truth were knowne, she hath proceeded.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How now, how speeds your businesse?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'me glad my Mothers come to part vs.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: How doe you agree forsooth?

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.p: As well as e're we did before we met.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.l: You put me to a Man I vnderstand not,
Your Sonne's no English Man me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: No English Man, blesse my Boy,
And borne i'the Heart of London?

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.l: I ha' been long enough in the chamber with him,
And I find neither Welch nor English in him.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Why Tim, how haue you vs'd the Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: As well as a Man might doe Mother, in modest Latine.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Latine Foole?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And she recoyl'd in Hebrew.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: In Hebrew Foole? 'Tis Welch.

sp.speaker: Tim.
